thread.title: U.S. Stocks Lower on Earnings, Data
thread.title_full: U.S. Stocks Lower on Earnings, Data

author: morningstar.com
title: U.S. Stocks Lower on Earnings, Data
text:
By Leslie Josephs and Tommy Stubbington
U.S. stocks' losses deepened Wednesday after Wal-Mart Stores Inc. issued a gloomy earnings forecast, sending its stock tumbling.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 117 points, or 0.7% to 16965.90. Wal-Mart tumbled 8.8% to $60.91.
The retailer surprised investors by predicting a sharp drop in earnings next year, citing in large part its pledge to raise wages for most U.S. workers and efforts to lift online sales.
Wal-Mart's move lower shaved close to 39 points off the Dow.
The S&P 500 was down 0.3% at 1998.2, while the Nasdaq Composite was down 0.2%.
The news came after data showing weaker-than-expected U.S. retail sales growth of 0.1% in September.
Investors were also grappling with mixed earnings reports.
"We had some mixed numbers," said Kenny Polcari, director at O'Neil Securities, referring to earnings reports.
Intel Corp. shares were down 2.6% at $31.22, after the chip-supplier reported a more than 6% drop in third-quarter profit.
J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. shares dropped 2.1% at $60.30 after the bank missed analysts' third-quarter estimates. J.P. Morgan reported after market close on Tuesday.
Bank of America Corp. shares rose 2% to $15.83 after the bank beat analysts' expectations for third-quarter earning s. TripAdvisor Inc. shares surged 19% to trade at $79.43 after Priceline Group Inc. agreed to list some of its travel websites on TripAdvisor.
Investors are looking ahead to the Federal Reserve's Beige Book, which is based on anecdotes in the Fed's regional survey of economic conditions.
European shares followed Asian markets lower after data showed lower-than-expected Chinese inflation in September, a day after disappointing import and export data from China dented stocks around the world. The consumer-price index rose 1.6% in September from a year earlier, compared with a 2% rise in August.
The Stoxx Europe 600 was down 0.4%, deepening losses from Tuesday.
Most Asian indexes declined amid fears Beijing would miss its year-end growth target. The Shanghai Composite Index closed 0.9% lower, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index lost 0.7% and Japan's Nikkei Stock Average fell 1.9%. China's third-quarter growth figures are due for release on Monday.
Chinese markets had initially rallied as the data propped up expectations for new stimulus measures, though the optimism quickly waned.
"Fears of imminent financial catastrophe were overdone. But most people see that the growth capacity of the global economy probably diminished over the summer," said Guy Foster, head of research at wealth manager Brewin Dolphin.
In currencies, the euro rose 0.4% against the dollar to $1.1435, while the dollar was 0.5% lower against the yen at Yen119.21.
In commodities, gold prices climbed 0.8% to $1,174.60 a troy ounce.
Brent crude oil was down 0.3% at $49.67 a barrel.
Write to Leslie Josephs at leslie.josephs@wsj.com and Tommy Stubbington at tommy.stubbington@wsj.com
(END) Dow Jones Newswires
October 14, 2015 12:30 ET (16:30
